ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: An improvement over object evolution with CPPNs
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Petar- I would really love to see some videos of this, or screenshots. Unfortunately, the screenshot link you provided did not work for me. Could you post

Hi Petar-

I would really love to see some videos of this, or screenshots.
Unfortunately, the screenshot link you provided did not work for me. Could
you post some files of screenshots to the yahoo group (or use tinyurl).

If you could post some videos that would be cool.

Sounds like fun stuff, but it is pretty hard to visualize just from your
descriptions. 


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Thu, 13 Nov 2008 23:36:24 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: An improvement over object evolution with CPPNs
> 
> I will try to change some options and update it. I will tell when it
> is updated. Is there anyone who had the same problem before? It is
> probably because I decided to install VS2008 to try it and stuff..
> There are files without this issue? Probably a missing service pack or
> something. 
> 
> I labeled it as explosion incorrectly. It is how to scale the
> coordinates for the 4D HyperNEAT part of the CPPN down to [-1 .. 1]
> without making large changes look insignificant to it.
> 
> But individuals with lots of cells should be also similar genetically.
> I will try a couple of ways to query CTRNN HyperNEAT substrates out of
> the cells and activate some kind of muscles..
> 
> I just uploaded a screenshot of the program here:
> 
> http://f1.grp.yahoofs.com/v1/cLEcSUHanK8oNKCt_ohekyObBbOcIkwsZI4aBmlJs
> BPkIvsyLtmXVJyeS3fO65IjAg9ZttpVKpwDI1y9czSXMgIZ-
> PvgpCtTEa9v9jO3yQ/dcppn_individual_in_development.PNG
> 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Peter, DCPPN_.exe seems to have a bug.  It crashes when I try to run
>> it.  It says, "the application configuration is incorrect" when it
>> crashes.
>> 
>> Can you explain a little more the coordinate explosion.  How many
>> coordinates are there once development is done?
>> 
>> ken
>> 
>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
>> wrote:
>>> 
>>> The executable is located in the Files section with the name
>>> "DCPPN_3.exe".
>>> 
>>> Yes I have the same opinion, that the links should be created
> after 
>>> development. But how should I deal with the "coordinate explosion"
>>> then? Because I don't really know how big the phenotype can get.
> There 
>>> is some limit, of course, but I am looking for an elegant way to
> solve 
>>> the problem. Rescaling to [-1..1] is more of a hack than a
> solution.
>>> 
>>> Peter
>>> 
>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
>>>> 
>>>> Peter, sounds interesting.  I'll be interested to see the
> executable
>>>> version to get an intuition of the kinds of structures your
> method
>>>> creates.  
>>>> 
>>>> About the links:  My guess is that it's best to compute their
> values
>>>> at the end of development since that is the "final geometry" of
> the
>>>> brain that I believe makes sense to exploit.  In other words, it
>>> gives
>>>> the brain the opportunity to exploit the changes occur over
>>>> development.  Otherwise, it would seem that those changes and
> the
>>>> genes that encode them are not really being used for any
> purpose.
>>>> 
>>>> ken
>>>> 
>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski"
> <petar_chervenski@>
>>>> wrote:
>>>>> 
>>>>> Hi all!
>>>>> 
>>>>> For those of you who are not familiar with this particular
>>> subject, it 
>>>>> is about physical object evolution with CPPNs. There are some
>>> problems 
>>>>> when trying to use CPPNs directly to map onto 2/3D objects
> with 
>>>>> finite, though variable (among individuals) size. I am
>>> particularly
>>>> interested in this issue because it also holds the key to the
>>>>> automatic generation of HyperNEAT substrates as well. And
> perhaps 
>>> it 
>>>>> may open up new ways to have content generation in games, too.
> And 
>>>>> Artificial Life, of course.
>>>>> 
>>>>> I remember that Ken suggested that animal morphologies and
> such 
>>> things 
>>>>> may be easier to describe in higher dimensional space and then
>>> mapped 
>>>>> back to 2D/3D, just like in HyperNEAT. Day after day I was
> trying 
>>> to 
>>>>> find such a higher-dimensional description of something that
> has 
>>>>> limbs, joints, all with variable numbers and size. Even in the
>>> most 
>>>>> simplistic 2D case, I never got even close to such an elegant
>>>>> solution. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> Suppose I want to have a 2D creature with rectangular limbs.
> But 
>>> how 
>>>>> many of them is unknown. How they are connected - too. A limb
> is  
>>>>> represented as position in 2D and width/height and an angle of
>>>>> orientation. This makes 5D space in which I have to query all
>>> possible 
>>>>> things and ask the CPPN if there is a limb or not. Sounds too
>>>>> expensive, and more, even if I do that, there are
>>>>> algorithmic/implementation issues that are just too hard.
>>>>> 
>>>>> The problem I had is, actually, that I missed the fact that a
> CPPN 
>>> is 
>>>>> an infinite mathematical description of the phenotype. Any use
> of 
>>> a 
>>>>> CPPN involves approximating the phenotype with some kind of
> level 
>>> of 
>>>>> detail. The CPPN makes no difference if I use it for 16x16
> visual 
>>>>> substrate or 65536x65536, for example (note: I mean not in
>>> phenotype 
>>>>> evaluation). So there must be a way to have such level of
> detail 
>>>>> scaling in animal morphologies as well.
>>>>> 
>>>>> So I went back to the cellular growth approach, looking for
> what I 
>>>>> missed before. The biggest unsolved problem with my previous
>>> system is 
>>>>> that coordinates may grow to infinite and the activation
> functions 
>>> are 
>>>>> actually best suited to work in [-1..1] substrates (given the
> fact 
>>> I 
>>>>> have fixed CPPN weight range and mutation powers). Plus, the
> CPPN 
>>> is 
>>>>> requeried on each cell on each timestep in the process of
>>> development. 
>>>>> Too expensive and as the phenotype gets bigger, development
> slows 
>>> down 
>>>>> to a rate that is not acceptable. And more, it is not clear
> how 
>>>>> scaling could work if I want to, say, have the same object,
> the 
>>> same 
>>>>> shape, much bigger, but the cell size and the coordinate
> frames - 
>>>>> still fixed. Something was terribly wrong with that model. But
> I 
>>> think 
>>>>> I have finally found a solution! Or at least something very
> close 
>>> to 
>>>>> it.
>>>>> 
>>>>> The CPPN already encodes all the development of a phenotype
> with 
>>> any 
>>>>> precision via composing coordinate frames. A whole phenotype
> with 
>>> all 
>>>>> its patterns with infinite (well at least huge) precision can
> be 
>>> fit 
>>>>> into just the patch of [-1 .. 1] in Cartesian space. Assume I
> will 
>>> be 
>>>>> talking about 2D space only for simplicity. That patch [-1 ..
> 1] 
>>> in 
>>>>> both X and Y I call "the Egg".
>>>>> 
>>>>> The first approach I took with the idea of the egg was too
> simple, 
>>> but 
>>>>> it is interesting to know about. After the CPPN "paints" the
> egg 
>>> with 
>>>>> cell color and stuff, then it is re-queried again, this time
> the 
>>>>> outputs are 2D vectors. The magnitude of these vectors was re-
>>> scaled 
>>>>> to be within [0 .. MAX_DISTANCE]. So the entire phenotype
> building 
>>>>> procedure became very simple - first build the egg, then send
> each 
>>>>> cell where its vector points. Well that looks so ugly in
> practice, 
>>>>> with empty holes and.. eh.. forget that! This is not anything
> more 
>>>>> advanced than just painting the CPPN output directly like in
>>>>> Picbreeder, just a fancy way of doing the same.
>>>>> 
>>>>> Then I realized that these "cells" can be also thought of an
>>>>> abstractions of "masses/groups of cells". In nature, cells
> don't 
>>> just 
>>>>> go "that way" moving through each other, but stick together.
>>> Entire 
>>>>> tissues develop fast as a mass of cells divides and increases
>>> size. So 
>>>>> I had this insight. I changed the concept of a cell and
> improved 
>>> over 
>>>>> the previous model. A cell is a circle with a radius, has a
> color 
>>> and 
>>>>> has mass. It also has more properties but more on that after a
> few 
>>>>> other words. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> This is the key idea. In my previous model, the CPPN was
>>> instructing a 
>>>>> big mass of many cells on the fly, during development time. It
>>> took 
>>>>> advantage of using time as input, so the development was like
> a 
>>>>> spatial pattern in 4D. But it suffered from the coordinates
> and 
>>> other 
>>>>> problems I mentioned above. In this model, the CPPN does not
>>> operate 
>>>>> on the cells during development. The CPPN predetermines the
> fate 
>>> of 
>>>>> each cell right in the egg, before development begins.
> Everything 
>>> else 
>>>>> during development is a consequence of the cell's fate and the
>>>>> internal 2D physics world in which the phenotype develops. So,
> in 
>>>>> simpler words, the CPPN is programming the egg.
>>>>> 
>>>>> A cell has the following properties that are determined by the
>>> CPPN:
>>>>> - Color (of course :)
>>>>> - Growth rate. How fast it increases size in % of circle area.
>>>>> - Time to begin growth. It is a value in [0 .. 1] where 1 is
> the 
>>> total 
>>>>> number of time steps allocated for development.
>>>>> - Growth time duration. Between some min and max value.
>>>>> - Angle for division splitting. Between [-1 .. 1], during
>>> development 
>>>>> rescaled to [0 .. pi]
>>>>> 
>>>>> As cells grow, they will inevitably overlap each other. This
> issue 
>>> is 
>>>>> handled by the internal simple 2D physics engine that adds
> forces 
>>> if 
>>>>> the circles overlap. So they eventually will converge to a
> state 
>>> that 
>>>>> they only touch each other, and the whole phenotype bigger of
>>> course. 
>>>>> Cells can divide. Division is automatic. If a cell's radius
>>> reaches a 
>>>>> a fixed treshold value, it is split into 2 cells, each one
> having 
>>>>> exactly half the area of the mother cell. The mother cell is
> split 
>>>>> along a predetermined angle, so the CPPN can control the
> overall 
>>>>> directions of growth for the phenotype. The 2 children overlap
> in 
>>> the 
>>>>> beginning, but as time progresses, they are pulled apart by
> the 
>>>>> physics. Children cells inherit the properties of the mother,
> but 
>>>>> change their positions and reset their lifetime timers. The
> cells 
>>> in 
>>>>> the egg count their children and their grandchildren as well.
> No 
>>> more 
>>>>> than 3 generations of division can occur, in order to keep the
>>> number 
>>>>> of cells relatively small for performance considerations.
> Though 
>>> this 
>>>>> value can be changed.
>>>>> 
>>>>> In order to keep the phenotype solid, not torn apart from
> internal 
>>>>> velocities, a mass-spring grid mesh is created in the egg
> before 
>>>>> development. Cell divisions update the mesh. The mass-spring
> mesh 
>>> plus 
>>>>> the cell-to-cell overlapping prevention forces act together as
> the 
>>>>> phenotype increases in size and number of cells. Eventually it
>>> will 
>>>>> become more stiff, where large group of recently divided cells
> are 
>>>>> packed together. I don't know if that is a bug or a feature :)
>>>>> 
>>>>> There is one insight I had after seeing the results. Watching
> the 
>>> mesh 
>>>>> develops, and some with interesting shapes and configurations,
>>> makes 
>>>>> me think this approach is very well suited to evolve HyperNEAT
>>>>> substrates as well. In fact I am about to add brains to these
>>>>> creatures right this evening :) But I don't know, if the links
>>> should 
>>>>> be determined from the beginning right in the egg or after
>>>>> development. Any suggestions?
>>>>> 
>>>>> Well this is it. I hope this may be some advance into the
> field. I 
>>>>> will be happy to see any thoughts about this stuff. I'll post
> an 
>>>>> executable compiled with VS2008 in the files section now, so
> you 
>>> will 
>>>>> see it in action. Note however, that it is just a demo of
>>> development, 
>>>>> not evolution. There is no doubt that this thing combined with
>>> NEAT 
>>>>> will make at least something very very cool. :)
>>>>> 
>>>>> Peter
>>>>> 
>>>> 
>>> 
>> 
> 
> 
>
